isis.stitle: VT-365 Diesel Engine Diagnostics (2002) - ENGINE SYMPTOMS DIAGNOSTICS - Test Procedures - Coolant Leak to Exhaust

svcsubproc.title: Coolant Leak to Exhaust Test Procedure

step1.para: Verify complaint of coolant leaking to exhaust.

item.para: Observation of coolant loss without engine overheating
Excessive white smoke from exhaust pipe on start up (hot or cold)
Check for coolant smell in exhaust
Check for coolant leaking from muffler

step1.para: Remove turbocharger exhaust tube (lower) following the procedures in the Engine Service Manual.

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury or possible death, use caution when removing turbocharger exhaust tube (lower) if coolant in tube could splash on technician or create slippery conditions.

step1.para: Check for presence of coolant in tube, right side exhaust manifold and EGR cooler exhaust inlet.
Plug in the cylinder block heater to warm coolant.

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury or possible death, use only the following procedure to remove the pressure type cap from the cooling system. Always allow the engine to cool first. Wrap a thick, heavy cloth around the cap. Loosen cap slowly; then pause a moment. This will avoid possible scalding by hot coolant or steam. Continue to turn cap to the left and remove.

step1.para: Remove the radiator cap and pressurize cooling system to 96 kPa (14 psi) using the radiator pressure tester.
Check EGR cooler exhaust inlet for the presence of coolant.

item.para: If coolant is present, replace EGR cooler following the procedures in the Engine Service Manual.
If no leak is found, but pressure is dropping rapidly, inspect the exhaust manifolds for coolant. Repair as necessary following the procedures in the Engine Service Manual.
If no leak is found, continue with step 7.

step1.para: Remove EGR valve and install Intake Manifold Pressure Test Plug (EGR) following the procedures in the Engine Service Manual.

figure.caption: EGR test plate, air regulator, and air gauge installed

step1.para: Install an air regulator onto EGR cooler pressure test plate and install onto EGR cooler exhaust inlet using original clamp. Follow the procedure in the Engine Service Manual.
Remove radiator pressure tester from coolant deaeration tank and fill tank with coolant to a point above the deaeration inlet line to tank. Leave radiator cap off.
Apply regulated air pressure of 172-414 kPa (25-60 psi) at the EGR cooler pressure test plate.
Observe coolant deaeration tank for air bubbles. Air pressure must be left on EGR cooler for a minimum of 5 minutes.

item.para: If air bubbles are observed in the tank, remove EGR cooler and retest following the procedures in the Engine Service Manual to verify EGR cooler is defective. Replace as needed.
If air bubbles are observed and EGR cooler passes additional testing, remove and pressure test the intake manifold following the procedures in the Engine Service Manual.
If no air bubbles are observed or EGR cooler and intake manifold have passed testing, contact Tech Services for further assistance.
